title: Bilateral Germany: A comparison of centralized and decentralized combinatorial auctions
abstractText: Combinatorial auctions (CAs) are multi-item auctions in which bidders can place bids on combinations of items, called ‘packages’, rather than just on individual items.  This allows the bidders to better express their valuations for items, which can lead to increased economic efficiency or higher revenue in the presence of synergistic values, ie where a package of items is worth more to a bidder than the sum of the individual values.  Combinatorial auctions have already found application in transportation, industrial procurement, and allocation of spectrum licenses for wireless communication services, among others.  Almost all combinatorial auctions today are centralized designs, meaning that an auctioneer collects bids and determines prices and the winning allocation. While determination of winning bids in a standard auction is a simple problem, the problem of determining the winning bids in a combinatorial auction—called the Winner Determination Problem (WDP)—is ineluctably difficult.  Decentralized CA designs can circumvent the WDP.  In this project, we will compare decentralized CAs with centralized CAs.  We aim to generate new results on the pros and cons of each of these approaches based on various bidder valuations and bidding strategies.
organisation: London School of Economics & Pol Sci
